text_result.title: Human
text_result.fulltxt:
<ul>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> a synonym for mankind and could formerly refer to specific individuals of either sex The latter use is now obsolete Generic uses of the term man are declining in favour of reserving it for referring specifically to adult males The word is from<strong>  . . .</strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> of the ideal human karyotype including both the male and female variant of the sex chromosome number 23 Like all mammals humans are a diploid eukaryotic species Each somatic cell has two sets of 23 chromosomes each set received from one<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> sets Among the 23 chromosomes there are 22 pairs of autosomes and one pair of sex chromosomes Like other mammals humans have an XY sex-determination system so that females have the sex chromosomes XX and males have XY One human genome was<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 </ul>
